item.value: take care of the mechanics.
take care of
The IntentService class exists to simplify this pattern and take care of the mechanics.
This "work queue processor" pattern is commonly used to offload tasks from an application's main thread.
work queue processor
the service is started as needed, handles each Intent in turn using a worker thread, and stops itself when it runs out of work.
Work Enqueuer
If the thread has been started, wait until the looper has been created.
A {@link Thread} that has a {@link Looper}. The {@link Looper} can then be used to create {@link Handler}s.
m Redelivery
All requests are handled on a single worker thread -- they may take as long as necessary (and will not block the application's main loop), but only one request will be processed at a time.
IntentService will receive the Intents, launch a worker thread, and stop the service as appropriate.
handles each Intent in turn using a worker thread, and stops itself when it runs out of work.
Clients send requests through {@link android.content.ContextstartService(Intent)} calls;
expressed as
IntentService is a base class for {@link Service}s that handle asynchronous requests (expressed as {@link Intent}s) on demand.
which uses jobs instead of services when running on Android 8.0 or higher.
IntentService is subject to all the <a href="previewfeaturesbackground.html">background execution limits<a> imposed with Android 8.0 (API level 26).
